byline.original: By BENJAMIN WEISER and MARC SANTORA

abstract: Unidentified juror asks to be excused from deliberations in federal corruption case against New York Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, citing difference in opinion with other jurors; request comes only hours after jury convenes to discuss verdict, which is highly unusual, an signal of how contentious deliberations in case have already become.
lead_paragraph: In a highly unusual move, a juror sent a note to the judge pleading to be excused less than two hours after the jury convened to decide whether Assemblyman Silver was guilty of fraud.

headline.main: Two Hours Into Deliberations, a Juror in the Sheldon Silver Trial Wants Out
headline.print_headline: 2 Hours Into Deliberations, Juror in Silver Case Wants Out

snippet: In a highly unusual move, a juror sent a note to the judge pleading to be excused less than two hours after the jury convened to decide whether Assemblyman Silver was guilty of fraud.
